column32:
Adarsa Azad Higher Secondary School is located towards southeast of densely populated
Bhaktapur city. It extends to an area of 2,171.656 sq. m., out of which 1,857.487 sq. m. is
found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Education, Science
and Technology. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for medical assistance
during a disaster. The updated survey shows no significant change in the usable area of
the site as there were no new structures in the area. The site is located on school grounds
and has a proper WASH facility that can be used during an emergency.

column32:
Airport Central Dojo is in the eastern side of Kathmandu Valley, near Tribhuvan International
Airport (TIA). It extends to an area of 21,328.91 sq. m., out of which 15,045.87 sq. m. is
found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The
previous study suggested the site to be feasible for humanitarian coordination area during
a disaster. According to the updated survey, major areas of the site are being used for
the construction of parks and a mall. These added structures in the site have significantly
reduced the usable area and its capacity to accommodate potential IDPs in an event of a
disaster.

column32:
Army Gold Club is located adjacent to Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA). It extends to an
area of 176,853.64 sq. m., out of which 122,758.135 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site
is under the ownership of the Pashupatinath Area Development Trust Board and the Civil
Aviation Department. The previous study suggested the site to be appropriate for multipurpose
use including military installation, civil-mil coordination center, warehouse and
humanitarian camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows that few structures were
constructed in the area. An addition of five buildings in the south-west corner of Army Golf
Club has reduced the usable open space area. As the site is guarded by the Nepal Army,
a detailed inspection of the site was not allowed. Consequently, the survey team could
assemble limited information about the site.

column32:
ANFA Football Ground (North) site is located nearby the dense settlement of Patan with its
proximity to Bagmati River. It extends to an area of 18,238.22 sq. m., out of which 14,475.51
sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the National Sports Council.
The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement camp in the event of a
disaster. The updated survey shows some structures added in the site. A building on the
eastern side, extension of the existing bleachers on the southern side, a new bleacher on
the western side, and two newly built gates have reduced the usable open space area and
its capacity to accommodate people during and after a disaster.

column20: Bagmati river flows in its vicinity

column32:
ANFA Football Ground (South) is in the southeast corner of Kathmandu Valley. It extends
to an area of 11,405.228 sq. m., out of which 10,368.818 sq. m. is found to be usable. The
site is under the ownership of the National Sports Council. The previous study suggested
the site to be feasible for vulnerable population assistance area during a disaster. Changes
observed during the updated survey include the addition of newly built structures: two
buildings near the entrance gate and commentary section office, a generator building and
bleachers in the new site have reduced the usable area of the open space. However, the
electric lights installed in the site aids in camp management during a disaster.

column32:
Bagmati Corridor 1 is located close to Tribhuvan University, southwest of Kathmandu
Valley. It extends to an area of 16,054.67 sq. m., out of which 13,027.18 sq. m. is found to
be usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous
study suggested the site to be feasible for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated
survey shows that three new buildings have been constructed in the site, reducing the total
usable open space area. However, a wall built alongside the river from north to south aids
in the camp management by reducing the flood risk.

column20: Bagmati river flows in its vicinity
column25: Yes Sparse vegetation and tress at roadside
column28: Yes (APF Chovar and Nepal Police near Chovar)
column30: Modern Indian School, Tribhuvan University
column32:
Bagmati Corridor 2 is in the southwest of Kathmandu Valley, near Tribhuvan University. It
extends to an area of 19,450.13 sq. m., out of which 18,795.18 sq. m. is found to be usable.
The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp and logistic hub during a disaster.
The updated survey shows three buildings added on the northwestern and eastern side
of water tank. Some land area in the northeastern side was occupied by being used as
garage. A bridge was constructed to connect Bagmati Corridor 2 with Oxygenation Park,
thus increasing the accessibility to the site. The addition of a few structures has reduced
the usable open spaces of the area.

column20: Bagmati river flows in its vicinity
column25: Yes Sparse vegetation and tress at roadside
column28: Yes (APF Chovar and Nepal Police near Chovar)
column30: Modern Indian School, Tribhuvan University, St. Marys School and St. Xavier's school
column32:
Bagmati Corridor 3 is in the southwest of Kathmandu Valley, near Tribhuvan University,
along the bank of Bagmati River. It extends to an area of 43,787.67 sq. m., out of which
31,766. 64 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu
Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/
camp and to be used as a logistic hub in the event of a disaster. The updated survey shows
temporary settlements in the bank of river. The temporary settlements consist of eighteen
buildings, four construction sites and a petrol pump. Being located in close proximity
to the river, the entire area is vulnerable to flooding. The addition of temporary and
permanent shelters has reduced the usable area significantly. With the reduced usable
and the vulnerability to floods, this updated survey concludes that the Bagmati Corridor
area is less favorable for settlement/camp during a disaster.

column20: Bagmati river flows close to the site
column28: Yes (Metropolitan Police at Teku and Sanepa)
column30: Nightingle School, Advanced Engineering College, Sagarmatha Engineering College
column32:
Bagmati Corridor 4 is in the southwest of Kathmandu Valley, along the Bagmati River.
It extends to an area of 15,994.22 sq. m., out of which 15,955.09 sq. m. is found to be
usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous
study suggested the site to be suitable for debris collection and dead body management/
morgue during a disaster. The updated survey shows new buildings in the site which have
reduced the total usable area of the open space and hence, less accommodation capacity
during an emergency. However, the addition of electrical poles and fences around the site
strengthens its capacity for camp management.

column20: Bagmati river flows close to the site

column32:
Bagmati Corridor 5 is in the southwest of Kathmandu Valley, along the Bagmati River.
It extends in an area of 20,705.69 sq. m., out of which 20,244.79 sq. m. is found to be
usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous
study suggested the site to be suitable for debris collection and dead body management/
morgue during a disaster. The updated survey shows the reduction of usable area due to
the addition of new buildings. As the area is close to the river, there is a high risk of flood
during the monsoon season. However, few electrical poles added in the area may aid in
the camp management if other factors are favorable.

column32:
Bagmati Corridor 6 is located close to the dense settlement of Patan. It extends to an area
of 6,261.10 sq. m., out of which 5,558.110 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the
ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested the site to be
suitable for debris collection during a disaster. The updated survey shows the reduction of
usable area due to addition of five buildings in the site. Moreover, the site’s proximity to
the river has further increased the risk of flooding. The addition of five electrical poles and
eighteen solar panels strengthens the camp management.

column32:
Balmiki Vidyapith is centrally located in Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area of 5,603.63
sq. m., out of which 4,578.12 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership
of Mahendra Sanskrit University. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable
for distribution and medical assistance during a disaster. The updated survey concludes
that new buildings and accommodation facilities in the school have been added. Five new
buildings have been built in the southern part of the school premises, which significantly
reduced the total usable area. However, as the identified open space is within the school
premises, it has a proper WASH facility that will strengthen the camp management during
an emergency.

column32:
Basu School is in the eastern side of Bhaktapur Durbar Square. It extends to an area
of 2,625.05 sq. m., out of which 1,738.97 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under
the ownership of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable for humanitarian camp during a disaster. The updated
survey shows the reduction of usable area for humanitarian camp due to the addition
of two buildings, one in the north of the garden and, another in the southwest part of
the school. There is also ongoing construction of a building south of the school gate. The
identified open space is within the school premises and has a proper WASH facility that will
strengthen the camp management during a disaster.

column32:
Bhaktapur Bahumukhi Campus is located south of the main road leading to Bhaktapur city.
It extends to an area of 25,970.81 sq. m., out of which 25,140.36 sq. m. is found to be usable.
The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology. The
previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster.
The updated survey shows the reduced usable area due the addition of three recent
constructions following the demolishing of an old building. The identified open space is
within the school premises and has a proper WASH facility that will strengthen the camp
management during a disaster.

column32:
Bhaktapur Durbar Square is centrally located in Bhaktapur and included in the UNESCO
World Heritage list. It extends to an area of 5,936.29 sq. m., out of which 5,307.52 sq. m. is
found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Department of Archeology. The
previous study suggested the site to be suitable to be used as a distribution area during
a disaster. Bhaktapur Durbar Square was highly affected by the Gorkha earthquake 2015
and numerous structures are still under construction. For renovation purposes, many
areas of the site are being used to store construction materials and people are not allowed
to enter those specific areas of the site. This has reduced the usable area temporarily.

Bhandarkhal is in the northeast of Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area of 21,238.277 sq.
m., out of which 12,042.689 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of
Pashupati Development Trust Board. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable
for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows the reduction of usable
area due to the addition of three buildings in the southeast corner of the site. The site is
close to Mahendra Ved Vidhya Ashram (School) which has a proper WASH facility.

column32:
Bhelukhel is in the densely populated area of Bhaktapur City, nearby the manure production
site in Bhaktapur. It extends to an area of 4,665.65 sq. m., out of which 4,523.95 sq. m.
is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Bhaktapur Municipality. The
previous study suggested the site to be suitable for logistical purposes during a disaster.
The updated survey shows addition of one building in the southern part and a temple in
the southeast of the identified open space, on the way to Jagati. Few parts of the site have
been used to store the construction materials. These added structures have reduced the
usable area of the site.

column32:
Bhrikuti Mandap is centrally located in Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area of
84,138.70 sq. m., out of which 66,338.84 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the
ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested the site to be
suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows the addition of
different kinds of facilities within the area. The addition of cafes on the western side was
observed during the updated survey. Similarly, two ponds, some benches and sheds were
constructed at the amusement park site. Tracks and fences were also constructed around
the area. These added structures have significantly reduced the usable area for settlement/
camp planning during an emergency. However, the exhibition ground is fenced which aids
in the security of the open spaces. Also, removal of two buildings in the southern part can
be noticed. The smaller open spaces scattered in the site are currently being used as a
playground and for filming and commercial purpose.

column32:
Birendra Sainik School is located along the main road leading to Bhaktapur City. It extends
to an area of 67,089.77 sq. m., out of which 64,589.20 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site
is under the ownership of the Nepal Army and the Ministry of Defense. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable for multiple purposes including civil-mil coordination
center, warehouse, medical assistance, helipad, humanitarian coordination, vulnerable
population assistance, telecommunication and for accessing potable water during a
disaster. The updated survey shows the addition of two buildings and two restrooms which
have reduced the usable area of the site. Likewise, the area is within the school premises
and has a well-managed WASH facility which is a key factor for the people residing here
during a disaster.

of Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area of 17,457.82 sq. m., out of which 13,767.110 sq.

The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster.
The updated survey shows no major changes besides a newly constructed building which
has slightly reduced the usable open space area.

Civil Aviation 2 is in the southern end of the runway of TIA. It extends to an area of
142,215.32 sq. m., out of which 117,155.44 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under
the ownership of the Civil Aviation Department. The previous study suggested the site
to be suitable for warehouse during a disaster. The updated survey shows the addition
of only a few constructions in the open space. This includes a badminton court in the
southwest part of the site, electrical poles and a tower in the southwest part near the
track, which have reduced the usable area of the open space. However, the electrical poles
installed in the site can be useful during camp management.

Civil Aviation 3 is in the eastern part of Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area of 76,292.66
sq. m., out of which 30,963.20 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership
of the Civil Aviation Department. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for
logistical purposes during a disaster. The updated survey found that recently constructed
aviation museum covers a significant area of this open space. In addition, four new
buildings and a gate have reduced the usable area and its total capacity to accommodate
displaced people during a disaster.

Dasarath Stadium is in the southwest of Kathmandu Valley, along the bank of Bagmati
River. It extends to an area of 32,249.58 sq. m., out of which 22,876.906 sq. m. is found to
be usable. The site is under the ownership of the National Sports Council and the Ministry
of Youth and Sports. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for multiple
purposes including humanitarian coordination, humanitarian camp and helipad during a
disaster. The updated survey shows ongoing renovation in the site. Hence, construction
materials were accumulated in some parts of the site. Accumulation of construction
materials have slightly reduced the total usable area in the site temporarily.

Valley. It extends to an area of 1,937.702 sq. m., out of which 1,625.736 sq. m. is found to be
usable. The site is under the ownership of Guthi Sansthan. The previous study suggested
the site to be suitable for medical assistance during a disaster. The updated survey shows
no major changes in the site besides one electricity pole added in the site. The usable area
has not been reduced and can be utilized during a disaster.

DWSS is located in the northeast corner of Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area of
57,347.23 sq. m., out of which 30,285.37 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the
ownership of the Department of Drinking Water Supply. The previous study suggested
the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. In the updated survey, the
addition of several wastewater treatment plants, and office buildings were observed. The
added structures along with old structures have almost occupied the entire area of this
site. Hence, previously suggested use for this site will not be applicable.

Election Commission Office is located at the center of Kathmandu district with dense
settlement near the identified site. It extends to an area of 16,168.61 sq. m., out of which
15,389.14 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of
Law, Justice and Constituent Assembly. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable
for multiple purpose including helipad, distribution area and telecommunication during a
disaster. The updated survey shows new constructions in the periphery consisting of four
buildings, two sheds renovated as a single building, and a garage. The recent construction
has reduced the usable area of this site. However, several electrical poles added in the site
can strengthen the camp management during a disaster.

Gokarna Golf Club is located about 10 km from the center of Kathmandu. It extends in
an area of 290,060.86 sq. m., out of which 237,390.65 sq. m. is found to be usable. The
site is under the ownership of the Department of Forests and Soil Conservation. The
previous study suggested the site to be suitable for multiple use including; logistics, civilmil
coordination, warehouse, humanitarian camp and for accessing potable water during
a disaster. According to the updated survey, no significant changes in the environment and
structure were detected on the golf course. However, due to security issues, the site could
not be accessed for detailed survey.

Gokul Chaur is located close to dense settlement of Patan, along the Bagmati River. It
extends to an area of 7,328.13 sq. m., out of which 7,302.18 sq. m. is found to be usable.
The site is under the ownership of Lalitpur Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested
the site to be suitable for distribution area during a disaster. The updated survey shows
the addition of three water reservoirs in the north, south and in the southeast respectively.
These structures have reduced the usable area of the open space. A walking trail has been
made in the center of the site for aesthetic purposes though slightly reducing the usable
area in the open space.

sq. m., out of which 122,758.135 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership
of Pashupati Development Trust Board and the Civil Aviation Department. The updated
survey shows no major changes besides one newly constructed building. The site is used
as a golf course and for military purposes. Since the area is guarded by the Nepal Army, a
detailed survey could not be carried out. A recent aerial image of the site does not show
major changes in terms of construction in the site.

Himal Cement Company is located in the southwest of Kathmandu Valley, near Tribhuvan
University, along the bank of Bagmati River. It extends to an area of 91,756.67 sq. m. The
site is under the ownership of the Himal Cement Company. The previous study suggested
the site to be suitable for logistical purposes during a disaster. As per the updated survey,
a dry port was under construction and no further study could be carried out. As the whole
area is being used for the construction of a dry port, the area may no longer suitable
for logistical purpose in the event of a disaster as proposed by the previous study. Once
construction is completed, the smaller area inside the location might be a usable open
space.

Central Zoo. It extends to an area of 7,501.69 sq. m., out of which 7,293.98 sq. m. is found
to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Machhindranath Development Trust
Board. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a
disaster. The updated survey shows a small walking path around the ground and no other
significant changes were seen in the site.

an area of 26,692.29 sq. m., out of which 24,082.28 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is
under the ownership of Bhaktapur Municipality. The previous study suggested the site to
be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows the addition
of few new structures including college buildings and facilities which have reduced the
usable open space area. However, proper WASH facilities available within this site will
strengthen the camp management during an emergency.

addition of few electrical poles strengthens the camp management during a disaster.

suitable for medical assistance during a disaster. The updated survey concluded that there
were no significant changes in the area and the open space can be utilized for medical
assistance during a crisis.

usable. The site is under the ownership of Lalitpur Metropolitan City. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable for multiple uses including warehouse, medical assistance
and helipad during a disaster. The updated survey shows no major changes in the area
and can be used for multiple purpose in the event of a disaster.

of Lalitpur Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable to be
utilized as humanitarian coordination area during a disaster. As per the updated survey,
the whole area has been converted into a park. The updated survey shows three buildings
in the southwest of the entrance gate, three transformers and several sitting benches in
the site. These structures have significantly reduced the usable open space area of the site.

study suggested the site to be suitable to be utilized as humanitarian coordination area
during a disaster. The updated survey shows two new buildings near the pond. As no other
major changes were detected, there is no significant reduction in the usable open space
area.

site to be suitable as distribution area during a disaster. The updated survey shows the
addition of ten buildings and some parts of the site have been used to deposit construction
materials. While this has significantly reduced the usable area of the open space, the site
has well managed WASH facilities.

city. It extends to an area of 8,354 sq. m. and the entire area is found to be usable. The
site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Education and Sports. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated
survey shows the addition of two buildings in the site which have slightly reduced the
usable open space area for settlement/camp. However, the site has a well-managed WASH
facility which strengthens the camp management during a disaster.

University, along the bank of Bagmati River. It extends to an area of 14,795.90 sq. m., out of
which 14,624.808 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Modern
Indian School. The previous study suggested the site to be feasible for settlement/camp
during a disaster. The updated survey shows the addition of a building at the northeast
corner of the site. Since, the site is inside the school premises, it has a well-managed WASH
facility that strengthens the camp management in the event of a disaster.

column32:
Narayan Chaur is located at the northeast of Kathmandu Valley inside the Ring Road.
It extends to an area of 10,209.74 sq. m., out of which 8,649.36 sq. m. is found to be
usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous
study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. According
to the updated survey, the whole area has been changed into a park which has completely
changed the landscape of the area and hence, reduced the capacity to accommodate
people during a disaster. Likewise, the new constructions in the park have slightly elevated
areas in all the edges and new tracks have been made. However, many electrical poles and
solar panels have been added in the area which will strengthen the camp management.
The site is commonly used as sports ground and for some leisure activities.

NARC is situated in Khumaltar of Lalitpur district, south of the Ring Road of Kathmandu
Valley. It extends to an area of 491,893.14 sq. m., out of which 393,214.52 sq. m. is
found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Agricultural, Land
Management and Cooperatives. The previous study suggested the site to be feasible for
several purposes including settlement/camp, logistics, medical assistance, distribution,
helipad, telecommunications and potable water source during a disaster. The updated
survey shows numerous greenhouse tunnels for research purposes within the site, which
has reduced the usable area for the proposed use as per the previous study. However, the
army camp near NARC and adequate water supply in the area can strengthen the camp
management during a disaster.

of 762.296 sq. m., out of which 726.545 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the
ownership of Bhaktapur Municipality. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable
to be utilized as distribution area during a disaster. The updated survey shows additional
constructions as two buildings were renovated in the southwest side of the site which
has reduced the usable area. However, the site has a large area and is suitable for the
establishment of a large IDP camp and as distribution points to the nearest clustered areas.

The National Academy is located in the densely populated central region of Kathmandu
Valley. It extends to an area of 24,423.20 sq. m., out of which 18,082.43 sq. m. is found to
be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Federal Affairs, Constituent
Assembly, Parliamentary Affairs and Culture. The previous study suggested the site to
be suitable to be utilized as a humanitarian camp during a disaster. The updated survey
shows the addition of three buildings and one temple. The structures have reduced the
usable area for humanitarian camp as proposed by the previous study. Nevertheless, the
attached Automated Teller Machine (ATM) and a well-managed WASH facility will aid in the
camp management during a disaster.

Dhobi Khola intersects the identified site. It extends to an area of 14,948.80 sq. m., out
of which 13,038.14 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the
Ministry of Women, Children and Social Welfare. The previous study suggested the site
to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows the
reduction of usable area due to few added buildings in the site. However, fencing around
the site adds to the security of location during camp management. Likewise, the site is in
the school premises and has a well-managed WASH facility that will strengthen the camp
management.

Oxygenation Park is in the Bagmati River bank opposite to Tribhuvan University. It extends
to an area of 359,400.56 sq. m., out of which 132,152.15 sq. m. is found to be usable.
The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Agricultural, Land Management and
Cooperatives. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for debris management
and setting up camps for IDPs during a disaster. The updated survey shows that two new
bridges have been added in its vicinity, which has increased the accessibility to this site.
Numerous electrical poles have been added which will aid in camp management during a
disaster. The small ponds in the site have now been covered with bushes.

sq. m., out of which 8,338.76 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership
of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology. The previous study suggested the
site to be suitable to be utilized as humanitarian coordination area during a disaster. The
updated survey shows three new buildings in the southern corner and one in the western
side. These buildings have reduced the usable area of the open space. This site is inside
the school premises and has a well-managed WASH facility which strengthens the camp
management during a disaster.

district. It extends to an area of 17,093.61 sq. m., out of which 12,230.61 sq. m. is found
to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Tribhuvan University. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated
survey shows the reduction of open spaces due to addition of new buildings northeast to
the campus office and south to Pragya hostel. The total usable area has been reduced to
some extent due to these new constructions. Furthermore, the open spaces in southeast
corner is being utilized for parking purpose. The open space is inside the college premises
and has a well-managed WASH facility which strengthens the camp management.

Pashupati 1 is located in the northeast corner of Kathmandu Valley. It extends to an area
of 17,981.45 sq. m., out of which 14,407.54 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under
the ownership of Pashupati Development Trust Board. The previous study suggested the
site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows that
the landscape of the site has drastically changed as the site has been turned into a recently
designed park. Both temporary and permanent structures have been built on the site.
Eight new buildings have been added along with a gate in the west and foot trails in the
center and in the southwest of the site. Plenty of open spaces are being used for vehicle
parking. Nonetheless, the site is fenced to the west which would strengthen the camp
management.

has been reduced significantly due to the construction of three buildings, four benches

during a disaster. The updated survey shows three new buildings in the southwestern side
which have reduced the usable area of the open space. A mini hydro power has been built
near to the open space. Pulchowk Engineering College offers additional facilities such as
catering and accommodation useful for the camp management.

Rastriya Sabha Griha is centrally located in Kathmandu Valley with relatively flat land and
with some vegetation. It extends to an area of 13,589.23 sq. m., out of which 11,194.50 sq.
m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City.
The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp. The updated
survey shows that the addition of seven new buildings which have reduced the usable
open space area significantly. There is a Frequency Modulation tower in the site and the
site has is close to the Mahendra Police Club, making security facilities accessible in the
area.

column32:
Ratna Park is located centrally in Kathmandu and is an assembling point for IDPs. It
extends to an area of 177,241.96 sq. m., out of which 138,814.07 sq. m. is found to be
usable. The site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous
study suggested the site to be suitable for multiple usages including camp, helipad, civilmil
coordination, medical assistance area and as a vulnerable population assistance area
during a disaster. The updated survey shows that a major area of the site has been occupied
by temporary constructions and is also being used as a construction materials deposit.
The iron pillars and fencing around the site aids in camp management. To the southern
part, lies the construction setup for new Dharahara (collapsed in April 2015 earthquake).
Sainik Manch is situated in the center of Ratna Park area used for military purpose. Khulla
Manch is used as bus park in northern side, while the northwestern part is being used to
deposit construction materials for the construction of Durbar High school. In total five
buildings have been built and two bleachers in the northwest and southwest part have
been constructed, while the remaining areas are same as that of previous survey.

NAST is situated in the southeast corner of Kathmandu Valley. The site is one kilometer
away from Ring Road. It extends to an area of 73,071.58 sq. m., out of which 63,198.08
sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of NAST and the Ministry of
Environment, Science and Technology. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable
for camp, medical assistance and to be utilized as a humanitarian coordination area. The
updated survey shows that the temporary setups and six new buildings have been built
in the area which have reduced the usable area of the site. However, the site has proper
WASH facilities in the office buildings which can aid in camp management during a disaster.

Sallaghari Tinkune is located near the Sallaghari Traffic Police post. It extends to an area of
66,896.13 sq. m., out of which 64,310.31 sq. m. is found to be usable. To the south of the
site is the Araniko Highway. The site is under the ownership of Bhaktapur Municipality. The
previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp. The updated survey
shows that five temporary buildings and deposits of construction materials in various parts
of the site have occupied the usable area of the open space. A fully fenced park has been
made in the southeast corner of the site and improper management of the drainage has
been a major issue of the site which might in turn hinder the camp management.

column32:
Sankha Park is located in the northern side of Kathmandu district. It extends to an area
of 10,751.35 sq. m., out of which 10,652.75 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under
the ownership of the Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested the site
to be suitable for debris collection as well as logistical purposes during a disaster. The
updated survey shows that the park has been well designed with three buildings, a control
and monitoring house, two resting platforms and a few stairs have been constructed which
has reduced the usable area of the site. One building located in the southeast of the pond
has been destroyed.

column17: Gyneshwor, Tangal, Naxal and Handigaun areas
column20: The site is intersected by Dhobikhola
column28: Yes (Nepal Police Headquater and Kamalpokhari Police Station)
column30: KIST College, ISMT College, Times International College
column32:
Sano Gaucharan is located in the northeast of Kathmandu Valley inside the Ring Road. It
extends to an area of 8,747.76 sq. m., out of which 7,822.89 sq. m. is found to be usable. The
site is under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested
the site to be suitable for distribution area during a disaster. The updated survey shows
that the renovation of bleachers has been done and the truss has been managed properly.
No major step has been taken to manage WASH facilities in the site. Since major changes
such as construction of new buildings were not observed in the site, there is no significant
reduction in the total usable area of the site.

column20: A pond is situated at the center of the site
column28: Yes (Bhaktapur Metro Range)
column30: Saraswati Vidhyagriha
column32:
Saraswati Vidya Griha is situated close to Kamalbinayak Buspark. It extends to an area of
2,985.43 sq. m., and the entire area is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership
of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology. The previous study suggested the
site to be suitable for logistical purpose during a disaster. The updated survey shows no
significant changes in the site. Since the open space is within the school premises, it has a
well-managed WASH facility which can strengthen the camp management.

column30: Kathmandu Valley High School, Orient College, British Gurkha College, Reliance College, Pasang Lhamu School, Canvas College, National College
column32:
Sifal Ground is located in the northeast of Kathmandu Valley inside Ring Road. It extends
to an area of 7,182.78 sq. m., out of which 7,176.91 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is
under the ownership of Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The previous study suggested the
site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows no
major changes besides a basketball court and a few electrical poles added in the site. The
drainage management system is the major issue of the site which hinders the site from
being suitable for the camp management during a disaster.

Social Welfare Council is centrally located in Kathmandu district. It extends to an area of 13,319 sq. m. The site is being used for the construction of residence of Vice – President and
hence the site could not be accessed for detailed survey. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable as vulnerable population assistance area. As the site is being used for
construction of residence of Vice- President, the previously suggested use will not be applicable.

column32:
St. Mary’s School is located at the center of Lalitpur district. It extends to an area of 10,825.32
sq. m., out of which 9,242.38 sq. m is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of
the Society of Jesus. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for humanitarian
camp during a disaster. The updated survey shows the addition of five buildings and two
parapets in the northwest and southwest part of the site. This construction has reduced
the usable area significantly. The site is within the school premises and has a well-managed
WASH facility which can strengthen the camp management.

column17: Jawalakhel, Kumaripati, Ekantakuna, Bhanimandal, Sanepa, Balkhu and Dhobighat Areas

column32:
St. Xavier’s School is situated at the center of Lalitpur district. It extends to an area of
20,908.39 sq. m. and the entire area is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership
of the Society of Jesus. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for humanitarian
camp during a disaster. According to the updated survey, the usable area of the site has
been slightly reduced due to recent construction of two buildings in the northern side, a
statue and a resting platform in the southeast of the site. The site is within the premises of
school and has a well-managed WASH facility which strengthens the camp management.

column32:
Suryamadi is located at Dattatraya Square, which is named after the temple Dattatraya,
situated in the middle of the square. It extends to an area of 795.61 sq. m., out of which
672.063 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Bhaktapur
Municipality. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for distribution
area during a disaster. The updated survey shows no significant changes in the site. A
Pratikshyalaya (waiting area) has been built and water facilities have been added which will
be useful during camp management.

column32:
Talako is located in the densely populated area of Bhaktapur city. It extends to an area
of 1,054.47 sq. m., out of which 1,032.36 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under
the ownership of the Bhaktapur Municipality. The previous study suggested the site to be
suitable to be utilized as distribution area during a disaster. The updated survey shows no
new constructions and the usable area of the site has not been reduced significantly.

column32:
Taumadi is located in the densely populated area of Bhaktapur city. It extends to an area
of 1,998 sq. m., out of which 1,670.49 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the
ownership of the Bhaktapur Municipality. The previous study suggested the site to be
suitable for humanitarian coordination area during a disaster. The updated survey shows
no significant changes in the area and the suggested use of this open space is not affected.

column32:
The Tibetan Refugee Camp is situated at the center of Lalitpur district. It extends to an area
of 5,982.58 sq. m., out of which 3,993.95 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under the
ownership of the Nepal Red Cross Society. The previous study suggested the site to be
suitable for medical assistance during a disaster. The usable area has been reduced due to
the addition of four new buildings in the site. No other major changes have been observed.

column17: Koteshwor, Naya Baneshwor, Gairigaon, Minbhawan areas
column20: International Airport is nearby its site

column30: Whitehouse College, Himalaya College, NASA Internatioanal College
column32:
Tinkune is located in the eastern side of Kathmandu Valley, near the Tribhuvan International
Airport. It extends to an area of 28,372.15 sq. m., out of which 28,365.647 sq. m. is found
to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Kathmandu Metropolitan City. The
previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster. The
updated survey shows no significant changes in this area. Numerous electrical poles and
solar panels have been added in the site. However, no initiatives have been undertaken for
the management and preservation of the open space.

column31: Security issues, waste management, poor parking management issue
column32:
Tribhuvan University is located outside the Ring Road but near the main population center
of Kathmandu. It extends to an area of 1,431,956.83 sq. m., out of which 716,132.585 sq.
m. is found to be usable. The site is under the ownership of Tribhuvan University. The
site includes the university grounds and an adjacent cleared block of land identified as
an oxygenation park. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for multiple
purposes including camp, assembly point for displaced, distribution, warehouse, medical
assistance, helipad and for accessing potable water during a disaster. The updated survey
shows a new building for T.U. service commission within the periphery. Since the site
is occupied by trees and vegetation in many areas, it cannot be utilized for temporary
shelters. The site has a well-managed WASH facility and can be suitable for multiple
purposes during a disaster.

column20: Bagmati river flows in its vicinity
column26: Norvic Hospital, Nidan Hospital, Sumeru Hospital
column28: Yes (Nepal Police Kupandole)
column30: Nightingale School, Sagarmatha English School
column31: River pollution and waste management issue
column32:
The UN Park in Gusingal is located southwest of Kathmandu Valley, along the Bagmati
River bank. It extends to an area of 81,380.22 sq. m., out of which 80,469.62 sq. m. is found
to be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Environment, Science and
Technology. The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp
during a disaster. The updated survey shows that the area has been made into a park and
the usable area has been reduced due to the added structures. Likewise, gabions have
been made in the few areas along the river which reduces the chances of flooding during
monsoon. Numerous electrical poles have been added in the site from south east to south
west which aids in the camp management.

column17: Patan, Chakupat, Kupondole and Shankhamul Areas
column20: Bagmati river flows nearby the site
column28: Yes (Police Bit Jwagal)
column30: Pulchwok Engineering College, Himalayan Engineering College
column31: Waste management issue, Open latrines, No surveillance of the site
column32:
The UN Park in Jwagal is located near the Bagmati River and is centrally located in Lalitpur
district. It extends to an area of 42,300.46 sq. m., out of which 40,847.32 sq. m. is found to
be usable. The site is under the ownership of the Ministry of Population and Environment.
The previous study suggested the site to be suitable for settlement/camp during a disaster.
The updated survey shows the reduction of usable area due to the addition of seven buildings
and one badminton court. The site is located close to water sources and the addition
of numerous electrical poles can aid in the camp management during a disaster.

column20: Bhaktapur Durbar Square is nearby the site
column28: Yes (Jagati Police Station and Nepal Army of Sainik School within 1.7km)
column30: Vidyarthi Niketan, Padma Higher Secondary School
column32:
Vidyarthi Niketan is located near Bhaktapur Durbar Square. It extends to an area of
2,230.230 sq. m., out of which 1,557.338 sq. m. is found to be usable. The site is under
the ownership of the Ministry of Education, Science and Technology. The previous study
suggested the site to be suitable as distribution area during a disaster. The usable area
has been reduced significantly due to the addition of six new buildings and one stage in
the south of the site. The site is within the school premises and has a well-managed WASH
facility which aids in the camp management.
